title:
Vitamin D concentration, obesity, and risk of diabetes:
a mendelian randomisation study
author: Afzal
author_address: Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Herlev Hospital, Copenhagen University Hospital, Herlev Ringvej 75, DK-2730 Herlev, Denmark
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on diabetes
rationale:
that genetically increased BMI is associated with low
plasma 25(OH)D concentration and with increased risk
of diabetes.
exposure_covariates_model: Adjusted for study, month of blood sample (to account for seasonal variation)
limitations_overall:
we studied white Danes only, and 25(OH)D
concentrations vary with sunlight exposure and skin
colour.

title: Causal Relationship between Obesity and Vitamin D Status: Bi-Directional Mendelian Randomization Analysis of Multiple Cohorts
author: Vimaleswaran
author_address: Centre for Paediatric Epidemiology and Biostatistics and MRC Centre of Epidemiology for Child Health, UCL Institute of Child Health, London, United Kingdom
hypothesis: Effect of body mass idnex on Vitamin D
rationale: We explored the causality and direction of the relationship between body mass index (BMI) and 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D]
outcome_population: Caucasian populations from North America and Europe
exposure_population: Caucasian populations from North America and Europe
exposure_genotyping_dataset: The genetic data for most studies were obtained from genome-wide association platforms, but for some studies, variants were genotyped de novo
n_SNP_difference_reason:
Used only SNPs validated in Li et al. 2010, Cumulative effects
and predictive value of common obesity-susceptibility variants identified by
genome-wide association studies
power_calculation_how: Simulations - no power actually listed though
limitations_overall: it is not possible to examine the influences arising from the extremes of non-linear distributions
limitations_pleiotropy: it could be argued that as the biological function for some of the BMI SNPs is yet to be established, there could be alternative biological pathways explaining their association with BMI. Using multiple SNPs to index BMI, we were able to minimise the risk of pleiotropic effects, as the effects of alternative pathways reflected by individual SNPs would be expected to be strongly diluted when combined in a multi marker score
limitations_population_stratification:
Combining large population-based studies from North America and Europe could lead to confounding by population stratification. however, we adjusted for geographical variation/principal components
in all analyses, which appeared adequate, as there was no
evidence for heterogeneity by continent for the allele score metaanalyses
limitations_statistical_power:
This method assumes linear relationships and may have less power to detect an effect than other IV methods. In our
analyses, the F-statistic was greater than 200 for all instruments used
due to our large sample size.
